title: Privacy in Interaction: Exploring Disclosure and Social Capital in Facebook

author: Nicole B. Ellison, School of Information, University of Michigan

segmentation: OK, well first I wanted to acknowledge my coauthors, who aren't here.

Fred Stutzman is postdoc at CMU currently, myself Rebecca Gray and Jessica VTech are all at Michigan State University in the Department of Telecommunications Information Studies in Media and then Cliff.
Lampe is at University of Michigan in the School of Information.
So I'm.
I'm a social scientist.
My background is in communication theory and research.
I'm interested in online technologies and their implications for interpersonal relationships and one line of work that we, our group at MSU, has spent a fair amount of time looking at.
Is the social network site Facebook and really thinking about what individuals get out of their use of the site.
So the theoretical framework that we use is social capital and that's what this paper is focused on.
Of course, with a kind of privacy twist, which is which is newer for us.
Social capital in very general terms, refers to the benefits that we receive from our social relationships.
In this case, this would be a community coming together to get to constructive community building.
Andrews talk this morning talked about getting things done and social capital really gives us a theoretical framework for measuring and thinking analytically about that process.
By getting things done, I just want to clarify.
I'm not talking about kind of concrete, explicit examples like building a house.
It could also mean social support.
Kind of, you know, a shoulder to cry on.
Kind of getting through, getting through life.
OK, so we've all probably seen something like this in our news.
Need question asking is a very specific instance of mobilizing the informational resources in our social networks and this is one of the foci of our recent work.
So here in this case I'm asking my social.
This is when I was in Boston for a few months on sabbatical.
I'm asking hey what should I do with my kids and get a I had a few responses, some more useful than others but really, you know when we're looking at kind of.
Fulfilling our everyday informational needs.
There's a lot to be said for going to our social social networks as opposed to a site like Google.
So for one thing, these are all people who know me.
They know the context of the kinds of things that I might enjoy.
Also, there's a degree of trust that I have with these individuals as opposed to kind of a faceless anonymous commentator on a site like Yahoo questions.
So a couple of things that I wanted to point out.
So one is that there is a norm of reciprocity.
That's kind of assumed here.
So the idea is that these folks are coming to my benefit or coming to my assistance.
If in the future I see one of them asking a question, I would probably be more likely to then kind of.
Extend the same the same courtesy in a site like Facebook.

There are really very few cues about attention, so the only way that I know whether someone saw my post in this kind of paying attention to me is if they explicitly take some action on the site, either answering a question or clicking like.
So really, we Andrew again talk to a bit about social grooming.
This idea that we are sending signals to our.
Social network that we care about them.
We're investing time in them, taking the time to answer a question is a form of social grooming on the site.
OK, here's another example of kind of social capital in action.
This is a kind of.
An emotional a request for emotional support, so here I'm complaining about a rough night I had with a sick child and this was 17 responses long.
The first are kind of start out with a lot of kind of social support and then actually there were people who were commenting and giving me kind of in more informational support.
So this is this would be an example of bonding social capital and in both of those cases those exam.
I am disclosing things about myself right to my social network and now of course to you and you know of course those you know.
The fact that I have a sick kid or that I'm in Boston, those are not very sensitive.
Personal information and obviously, given that I'm sharing them with 300 people, many of whom are strangers, I had to kind of choose things that would be less less sensitive.
But in other cases you can imagine that I might be disclosing things that are more personal, right, or that I might not want.
Hundreds of people to know.
So for instance, undiagnosed with a health condition.
I'm looking for a new job, right?

These are things that are more sensitive and so control over our personal information is complicated by digital tools, because when you share something online, you lose a lot of control over where it goes and who has access to it.
There's a lot of attention recently that have been paid in popular press and also kind of popular narratives about privacy issues, and specifically with Facebook.
So for instance, this is a New York Times article that came out in the last.
Week or so, it's about a new breed of apps that are for maintaining control over your personal information.
One of the examples this article talks about is a app that basically deletes photograph after a certain amount of time.

You can share a photograph and then it kind of self destructs after an hour or two and you know there's a whole set of practices that have emerged where people are doing that as well so they are posting something on Facebook and then deleting it after a day or two and or.

In some cases, even closing their entire account and then going back in a few days and opening the account again, and these are attempts to really address the persistent quality of digital information.
But even deleting content isn't necessarily always successful.
So for instance, people can take screenshots of posts that.
You have on Facebook, even if you then later delete them.
Here's an example of a website where the sole purpose is archiving deleted tweets by politicians and you can see that it here.
It lists how long they were up when they were deleted, and the content of the message.
So you can see that this is kind of in a constantly evolving set of social practices and technological affordances.
So why is control over information an issue in Facebook?
And it has to do.
The nature of the connections that we articulate in these social network sites.
So here's just a kind of a snapshot of my Facebook friends Network and this is a kind of represent representative sample of both very strong ties and weak ties.
So I know these people from different contexts.
I have different relationship strains with them.
I have.
My brother is here some graduate students that I'm very close with.
Even I'm in the picture of her graduating and yet there's other people who I knew from high school who I.
You know, quite frankly, would not recognize if I pass them on the street and others who are professional Contacts but not necessarily close friends or even actual friends in some cases.
And this kind of heterogeneous net.
Art composition really complicates self presentation and practices.
So Erving Goffman is a sociologist who did a lot of work looking at self presentation and the idea here is that we are presenting different aspects of our identity to different audiences.
And you can think about kind of different facets of yourself and how they are associated with different contexts.
Different groups of people, and each of these groups of people or separate contexts have their own kind of set of norms and expectations.
So it doesn't necessarily mean you're being dishonest, but we act differently in different situations.
And of course, social network sites complicate this process because.
Of what some scholars call context collapse and the idea here is that context collapse is a process whereby these diverse sets of individuals, right?
So the network graph is kind of showing me with my different.
You know, my high school friends, my professional Contacts, my neighbors.
For instance, my family.
These would all be groups that wouldn't necessarily interact, and when they are flat, and as they are in a social network site or in a kind of Facebook friends network.
It becomes much more complicated to try to kind of tailor self presentation and disclosure practices to that particular kind of cluster of your network.

The kind of Canonical offline example of this is a wedding, and weddings can be very uncomfortable because these typically they bring together different parts of your life and these are different people who wouldn't necessarily ever come together.
And now you're kind of forced to simultaneously.
Interact with all these different clusters and so the same thing is happening to some extent in social network sites because we have networks that are hundreds of people.
All of whom are from different different contexts.
So the paper that I'm presenting today looks at different strategies that people use for managing their disclosures in their privacy concerns.
And what are the social capital implications of those various practices?
So, as I said, we have a.

Stream of research that looks at social capital and specifically at Facebook, and looking at the social capital implications of Facebook use and we argue that Facebook contains a set of social and technical affordances that can help people mobilize the resources that are kind of embedded or inherent in their in their social networks.
Social Capital is a theoretical framework.
As I said, that describes the ability of groups or individuals to access these resources.

Reciprocity is kind of embedded in a lot of these definitions, so this idea that you're investing in social relationships with expected returns in the marketplace and the marketplace in this sense is kind of a social marketplace.
If you will.
There's 2 Putnam is.
Is kind of credited with popularizing social capital more recently and he talks about two different kind of strands of social capital.
So bridging social capital is typically associated with weak ties.
Weak ties tend to be more likely to be different from from us, and also tend to have access to novel information and kind of diverse perspectives.
In particular, bridging ties which are kind of connecting to.
Guys unconnected clusters can.
That's very kind of powerful position to be in your.
You have access to different information that can be that can when you're in that brokering position.
That can be very useful.
And I'll point out that Judith Donath and Dana Boyd in 2004.

Talk about the the notion that social network sites kind of enable us to manage these larger networks and that the benefits of those larger networks would be presumably this increase of kind of novel information.
So bridging social capital bonding social capital is typically associ.
With strong ties such as close friends or family members, and the benefits that we tend to get from those kinds of ties are kinda big favor.
So you need 1000.
You need a loan of $1000.
You're not going to kind of go to a friend of a friend of a friend.
You're going to call a family member.
Social support is another is closely associated with bonding social capital.
This is some work that has some empirical work that has linked social.

Perceived social capital levels with social network site use and we think this is because there's a number of things going on, so it's very easy to broadcast requests for informational social support.
You are typically, you may have access to this diversity of viewpoints, different kinds of.
Different kinds of more heterogeneous networks.

It is fairly easy to signal that you want to invest in relationships and engage in social grooming and then also the identity information in profile can help you find common ground with people so kind of what you have in common.
The question that we're asking here is kind of in what way is my privacy.
We affect social capital.
And what we're doing in the.

This work then, as we're kind of bringing together 3 areas of literature that haven't yet been synthesized, so we're looking at disclosure patterns, social capital, and then privacy attitudes and behaviors.
We this is a survey data so we.
We invited 2500 undergraduates at a large Midwestern University to take our survey, and we had a set of questions about that I'll go into actually in a moment about different measures.
Our response rate was low, but not inconsistent with other work in this in this area, so our primary DV was social capital measures.
This is a.
From Dimitri Williams work in JCMC.
From a few years ago, we and other people doing work in this area who have used these scales an essentially they are reporting the extent to which you with bonding social capital.
Feel like you have these resources.
These strong ties that would help you in an emergency for instance or with bridging social capital.
Kind of exposure to new new ideas.
OK, then we had a number of Facebook use measures, one new.
Newer measure that we're using we're calling signals of relational investment, and it's a 5 item scale with a decent Alpha.
You could.

These are these are the items, so people are kind of agreeing with with these statements, and you can see that we Andrews talk, and I think Irene's question as well, was really getting at this notion of how the costs of social relationships and the idea here is that these are things that we do to signal that we are paying attention to our friends where.
You know, if we see someone asking a question, we are trying to answer it.
The one that's a little different that I'll point out is the happy birthday Facebook.
When someone is someone's Facebook friend has a birthday.
I try to post something on their wall that is kind of a peer social grooming behavior there.
OK, and we have a set of kind of theoretically and empirically derived explanations for why we.
That is a powerful set of behaviors, so part of it has to do with this fact that you are the reciprocity norms.
Social grooming.

This idea that you're kind of signaling that you're paying attention there also may be kind of a technical explanation here that when you were answering when you are posting to other people's wall and they're responding, you know this is a signal to Facebook and to Facebook's algorithm that that you are relevant to one another and.
And this may increase the visibility of you and your communication partner in one another's feeds, and then of course from a rolling births work.
We know that.
Access to different networks is very powerful, so when I comment in my own status update, I'm basically already only speaking to people that I already know.

If I go to Pauls News Feed and comment on something that he said I'm actually making myself visible to his network, and so there's kind of an increased attention that invisibility that I'm having to a whole new set of of resources.
OK, we're also looking at the composition of the network, so the idea that.
We used to just look at ask at how many total friends you have.
Now we are asking how.
Many of these friends do you consider actual friends and we're using the ratio of that, and roughly, it's about 1/3 to 1/4 of our network.
We would consider actual friends, and this is in adults and undergraduates.
We have a disclosure scale that measures how much people kind of disclose to their Facebook friends.
We also ask about privacy.
Concerns this is a scale that Fred has used in other work and.
And the extent to which they are using privacy settings.

So the first one here is I've limited my profile to friends only and the 2nd is whether you've used something like circles or listen Facebook to have content that you only send to some people and so people.
Could either you know so 59% of our sample did both, 6% did neither.
And other controls.
We did a path model where we were looking just real.
He basically just at a.
Basic level to see whether our kind of hunch that privacy behaviors and attitudes didn't necessarily have a direct.

This doesn't tell us that much.

Of limiting your profile to friends only and you can see that that is.
Is significant the interaction there?
Although when we look at our other privacy measure, it's not what I want to hear.
We've kind of plotted the interaction.

I want to point out that the kind of highest levels of bonding social capital are reported by people who have very high levels of actual friends in their network and to limit their profile to friends only.
And we hypothesize that this is because they feel more comfortable disclosing personal information because they know it's only going to a person set.
And if you think about bonding, social capital and social support disclosure, disclosing sensitive information would really be kind of a key thing to look at.
When we look at bridging social capital.
Here are the control.
Is the Facebook variables the Internet?
And that was significant with bonding is not.
However, when we look at friends.
Trolls and friend ratio.
It is significant and friend controls.
I'll remind you is where you limit certain disclosures to a subset of your network.
So I say I'm looking for a new job and I only show it to a very small percentage of my people.
I want to point out that this is negative, So what this means is that if you're doing that, you.
You know, in kind of crude terms, you are lowering your possible social capital gains because you are not able to harness the power of your entire network.
And so again, the kind of highest levels here are.

People who don't aren't using those friend controls who aren't who are just basically making disclosures to everyone, even though it may bore them even though they may not be appropriate, even though they may have privacy concerns and the idea here is that with bridging social capital, you really want to harness this very wide network and so that is actually a kind of positive strategy in that sense.
So just in conclusion, are the contributions of this work.
I think one is the measure of Sri the signals of relational investment in giving back the notion that network composition matters, that all friends aren't equal.
And then this idea that from their theoretical model that privacy behaviors are impacting disclosures which are then impacting social capital.
So there's that mediating effect, and from a privacy perspective you know, thinking about bonding social capital that engaging in privacy behaviors is a.

Speaks to kind of the benefits of being able to disclose in terms of bridging social capital, there's actually a cost to that, and so one thing I think that we would want to think about is kind of how can we design systems that allow people to maximize their social capital gains while still maintaining control over their personal information.
Thank you.
